prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. There are 12 different-colored crayons in a box. How many ways can Karl select four crayons if the order in which he draws them out does not matter?
solution:
There are 12 ways to select the first crayon, 11 ways to select the second, 10 ways to select the third, and 9 ways to select the last. However, since order does not matter, we must divide by the number of ways he can draw out the crayons, which is $4!$.

The answer is $\dfrac{12\times11\times10\times9}{4!}=\boxed{495}$ ways.
gpt_response: Let's see how many ways Karl can choose four crayons from the box. First, Karl can choose any one of the 12 different-colored crayons. Then, he can choose another one from the remaining 11 crayons. After that, he can choose another one from the remaining 10 crayons. Finally, he can choose the last one from the remaining 9 crayons. So, that means Karl can choose four crayons in 12 x 11 x 10 x 9 = 11,880 ways! Isn't that a lot of ways to choose crayons? Let's get coloring!
solution_prompt: Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 495?: Let's see how many ways Karl can choose four crayons from the box. First, Karl can choose any one of the 12 different-colored crayons. Then, he can choose another one from the remaining 11 crayons. After that, he can choose another one from the remaining 10 crayons. Finally, he can choose the last one from the remaining 9 crayons. So, that means Karl can choose four crayons in 12 x 11 x 10 x 9 = 11,880 ways! Isn't that a lot of ways to choose crayons? Let's get coloring!
gpt_response_correct_incorrect: Yes. The final solution obtained is 11,880, not 495.
